metadata.case_name: Pannalal Binjraj & Ors. v. Union of India
metadata.case_number: Original Jurisdiction Petitions Nos. 97, 97A, 44, 86 to 88, 111, 112, 85, 158, 211 to 251 and 225 to 229 of 1956

facts.text: Petitioners in Petitions Nos. 97 and 97A are Ms. Pannalal Binjrai (oil mill owners, merchants, commission agents at Sahibganj with branch at Calcutta) and R.B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury (karta of HUF Ms. Pannalal Binjraj). Assessed by ITO Special Circle Patna before September 28, 1954.
Central Board of Revenue order dated September 28, 1954 transferring cases of petitioners to ITO Central Circle XI Calcutta.
Central Board of Revenue order dated January 22, 1955 transferring petitioner No. 2's cases to ITO Central Circle VI Delhi; July 12, 1955 transferring petitioner No. 1's cases to same officer.
ITO Central Circle VI Delhi instituted proceedings post-transfer, including assessments and penalty for non-payment.

Petitioner in Petition No. 44/56 is Shri A.L. Sud, sole proprietor of Amritlal Sud Construction, resided in Calcutta since 1948, originally from Hoshiarpur Punjab. Assessed by ITO Special Survey Circle VII Calcutta prior to June 29, 1955.
Central Board of Revenue order dated June 29, 1955 transferring case to ITO Special Circle Ambala, who continued proceedings and assessed for 1946-47 and 1947-48.
Petitioners in Petition No. 85/56 are Ms. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons, merchants in rosin and turpentine at Hoshiarpur. Assessed by ITO Hoshiarpur before October 20, 1953.
Commissioner of Income-tax order dated October 20, 1953 transferring case to ITO Special Circle Ambala under s.5(7A), who reopened assessments 1944-45 to 1950-51 and completed some.
Shri A.L. Sud is member of HUF Ms. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons.

Petitioners in Petitions Nos. 86,87,88,111,112,158 (Amritsar group): Sardar Gurdial Singh, Dr. Sarmukh Singh, S. Ram Singh (brothers), S. Narain Singh (father), Hindustan Embroidery Mills Pvt Ltd (directors). Assessed by ITO A Ward or F Ward Amritsar before transfers around June 29, 1953.
Commissioner orders around June 29, 1953 transferring to ITO Special Circle Amritsar; notices u/s 34 for 1947-48 to 1951-52 issued.
Petitioner in Nos. 211-215: Nandram Agarwalla, sole proprietor Sriram Jhabarmull (import/export, commission agents at Kalimpong with Calcutta branch). Assessed by ITO Jalpaiguri before transfers.

Multiple transfers: March 5, 1946 to Central Circle I Calcutta; later to IV; June 8, 1946 back to I; July 27, 1946 by Commissioner Central Calcutta u/s 5(7A) to Central Circle IV Calcutta. Pre-Constitution orders.
Petitioner in Nos. 225-229: Kalloor Siddannal, commission agent at Raichur Hyderabad. Assessed under Hyderabad Act then Indian Act by Additional ITO Raichur.
Commissioner Hyderabad notification December 21, 1953 u/s 5(7) transferring to ITO Special Circle Hyderabad; notices issued 1954-55; assessments March/April 1955; application u/s 27.
Commissioner order shortly before May 19, 1955 u/s 5(7A) and 64(5)(b) transferring back to main ITO Raichur.
Cases of petitioners 97/97A referred to Income-tax Investigation Commission for evasion exceeding Rs. 8 lakhs, widespread activities.

Post Surajmull Mohta (1955), 320 cases reopened u/s 34(1A); special circles created at Bombay/Calcutta for quick disposal; petitioners allotted to Calcutta then to Delhi Central Circle VI due to workload.
Post Meenakshi Mills (1954), 470 cases reopened; more circles created; transfers for administrative convenience.
A.L. Sud and HUF Bhagwan Das Sud Sons evaded large amounts, inter-related transactions, widespread activities in multiple places.
No objection raised by Amritsar and Raichur groups until after Bidi Supply Co. decision on March 20, 1956.
Accounts examined at places convenient to assessees in several cases.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.5(7A) of the Indian Income-tax Act is ultra vires the Constitution as infringing Articles 14 and 19(1)(g).
Whether specific transfer orders are omnibus/wholesale and invalid per Bidi Supply Co., or discriminatory/mala fide.
Effect of Explanation to s.5(7A) added in 1956.
Maintainability of challenges to pre-Constitution transfers and where no timely objection raised.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.5(7A) invests naked arbitrary power to transfer cases without guidelines, discriminatory, picks one assessee over others similarly situated, violates right under s.64(1),(2) to local assessment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.14, Art.19(1)(g); s.64(1),(2); Bidi Supply Co. (minority view); Anwar Ali Sarkar

petitioner_arguments.text: Transfers cause inconvenience/harassment (e.g., Calcutta to Delhi/Ambala), substantial discrimination.
Omnibus orders not contemplated by s.5(7A); s.64(5) consequential and invalid.

respondent_arguments.text: S.5(7A) for administrative convenience to deal with special cases (widespread activities, evasion); no discriminatory procedure, same assessment rights/appeals.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Income-tax Amendment Act 1940; affidavit of Gouri Shankar

respondent_arguments.text: S.64 right not absolute, yields to tax collection exigencies; transfers minimize inconvenience, hearings at convenient places.
Discretion in high officials, presume bona fides; abuse remedied case-by-case, not invalidate section.
Explanation to s.5(7A) validates omnibus orders covering all proceedings.
Pre-Constitution orders valid; no timely objection in some cases, acquiescence.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.13 no retrospective effect; Keshavan Madhava Menon

court_reasoning.text: S.64(1),(2) confers benefit/right to local assessment but subject to tax collection exigencies; not absolute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right hedged by exigencies; transfers for convenience/efficiency not discriminatory.

court_reasoning.text: S.5(7A) administrative machinery for efficient assessment; guided by Act's purpose (assessment/collection); discretion not naked/arbitrary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vested in high authorities; presume proper exercise; minor deviation from s.64 not material discrimination.

court_reasoning.text: No impingement on fundamental right; inconvenience not substantial, minimized by convenient hearings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Does not violate Art.14/19(1)(g); abuse challengeable individually.

court_reasoning.text: Explanation expands 'case' to all proceedings pending/ future; validates transfers for closed cases via s.34 etc.
Pre-1950 orders not challengeable under Art.32; acquiescence in Amritsar/Raichur; no discrimination in facts (evasion, workload).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Specific orders bona fide for administrative reasons.

court_reasoning.text: Prudent to give notice/hearing/reasons under s.5(7A) where feasible.

holdings.text: S.5(7A) intra vires, not violative of Art.14 or 19(1)(g).
Transfer orders valid, not discriminatory/mala fide; omnibus saved by Explanation.
Petitions by Sriram Jhabarmull, Raichur, Amritsar groups not maintainable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Omnibus orders not contemplated originally; left constitutionality open; minority view noted but not adopted.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Discrimination principles; minor deviations not violative of Art.14.
Led to amendment inserting s.5(7A); s.64 for local assessment as far as practicable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay
Dwarka Prasad v. State of UP
Himmatlal Harilal Mehta v. State of MP
Surajmull Mohta v. A.V. Viswanatha Sastri
Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Viswanatha Sastri
precedents_cited.relevance: Struck down s.5(1) Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer of cases; place of assessment; overrides local assessment post-transfer.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Enforcement of fundamental rights; equality; trade/business; laws inconsistent with Part III.

statutes_cited.name: Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947 (XXX of 1947)

outcome.summary: The Court upheld the validity of s.5(7A) as not violative of Arts.14 or 19(1)(g); specific transfer orders valid and not discriminatory; petitions by certain groups not maintainable due to pre-Constitution orders, acquiescence; all petitions dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "S.5(7A) is a provision for administrative convenience... power is guided and controlled by the purpose... to be exercised for the more convenient and efficient collection of the tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on validity of s.5(7A).

key_quotes.text: "There is no fundamental right in an assessee to be assessed in a particular area or locality."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It would be prudent if the principles of natural justice are followed... notice is given... reasons reduced to writing."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The power which is vested... is not a naked and arbitrary power... cannot be urged that such power... is discriminatory."
key_quotes.speaker: court
